text:
hickory dickory dock I'm holding one
grey sock in the other there are two and

both of them are blue hickory dickory
dock did you enjoy my little poem?

welcome everyone to another full English
video lesson coming to you from England

which happens to be the birthplace of
Cadbury chocolate Bakewell tart

Yorkshire pudding and my favourite...
spotted dick and of course the English

language which is the reason we are all
here today so take a deep breath open a

few windows make a nice hot beverage
because today's full English lesson is
going to start right...
now!

one of the hardest parts of doing
something creative is coming up with new

ideas figuring out new ways to do
something or finding new angles on which

to focus can really leave you in a spin
a clear head and a positive outlook are

both important when it comes to being
creative

sometimes those new ideas do not come
easily so you have to put your thinking

cap on that's a great expression if you
are stuck for an idea then you might

have to put your thinking cap on you
will need to come up with a new idea you

will have to wrack your brains to wrack
your brains is to think long and hard

about how to do something that seems
impossible I've been wracking my brains

all day over how to make some extra
money if more than one person is

involved with the new ideas then it
might be easier to come up with

something they say that two heads are
better than one we need to put our heads

together and try to solve this problem
sometimes it is not possible to come up

with any solution or new idea there is
nothing in your head we call this a

block for example there is writer's
block there are no new ideas in your

mind being creative is fun but it can
also be a nightmare when it comes to
creating new ideas

you may have noticed that I love English
some of my favorite English words happen

to be the smallest and the most commonly
used a good example is the word off it

seems like such a simple word yet it is
often used on a daily basis in so many

ways to cancel something can be
described as being off sorry girls the

football match is off you can call
something off we had to call off the

outdoor concert because of the rain
to have a free day away from work can be

described as being off I won't see you
tomorrow as it's my off day you are

having the day off another use of Earth
Day is when things keep going wrong or

when your mood is not good during a
certain period of time sorry for all the

mistakes guys I'm having a bit of an off
day to make your way out of a place or

to announce your departure you can say
that you are off okay guys it's 5

o'clock
see you tomorrow I'm off if something

that is perishable has gone past its
best then we can say that it is off

don't drink that milk it's off this
salmon smells awful I think it solved if

something has been disconnected from its
power source we can say that it is off

the TV isn't broken it's off talking of
which I'm off over there it's time to do
the next sequence

it's strange how some words can find
themselves together in English phrases a

good example of this is the phrase love
hate these words have opposite meanings

however they do go together as a
description of a certain type of

relationship I am talking about a
love-hate relationship in society a

love-hate relationship describes a
partnership that involves both fondness

and hatred a tumultuous or turbulent
relationship between two people can be

described as love-hate we had a terrible
fight last night but today we made up

and are having a meal together tonight
you might feel that this relationship is

based on love/hate especially if the
arguments occur often a long-term

relationship might become unstable due
to a hopeless feeling of routine and

familiarity the couple might become
bitter and resentful which results in

the up-and-down nature of the
relationship a love-hate relationship

can exist in other places if you love
your job

but it does not pay very well you might
have a love-hate relationship with it

you might have a love-hate relationship
with your boss there are some good days

and some bad you have mixed feelings you
have the feeling of both love and hate

it's now time for another buzzword a
buzzword is a word or phrase that is

popular during a certain period of time
or is often used generally today's

buzzword is discrimination the word
discrimination is a noun that names the

unjust or prejudicial treatment of
different categories of people

especially on the grounds
of race religion gender sexuality or age

the state of prejudging a person based
on their differences to show prejudice

toward someone because of their
differences is discrimination you can't

dismiss me because I'm a Muslim that's
discrimination to hold bias towards one

or more groups of people around you in
everyday life is discrimination you act

on a grudge against someone because they
are different from you this is defined

as discrimination the word can also name
the ability to define what is

high-quality
or good taste your discrimination picks

out what is worthy the verb form of
discrimination is discriminate you

discriminate between two or more things
by making judgments to discriminate is

to be prejudiced you display prejudgment
you are biased you carry out
discrimination

what do you want and what do you need if
you want too much can we call this greed

do you have more than you need or is it
enough perhaps you have nothing

sometimes life can be tough there is a
fine difference between the things you

want and the things you need to want is
to desire it is an urge to satisfy that

desire to need is the instinctive
response to nature's call for survival

it's the need to survive what is
necessary to survive is your need the

obvious things needed for survival are
food and water they are your basic needs

without these you will not survive for
long of course want can be classified as

need to however we often see want as a
more selfish emotion I need food I want

a nice new car to show my neighbor
furthermore the dilemma of what many

years creates quite a paradox we need
money to buy food but we also want money

to support a comfortable and some might
say wasteful lifestyle want is often

seen as a selfish emotion Mead comes
from your basic necessities want comes

from the things that will make you feel
better as a person need comes from the

basic survival instinct to make it
through the day without starving to

death need and want might have similar
definitions but they are often seen as
belonging to very different urges

what is a split infinitive? is it painful?
will it leave a scar? well first of all

having a split infinitive is not an
injury although it does sound like one

in English grammar we name a certain
grammar error as a split infinitive an

infinitive in English grammar is the use
of the word two with a verb while there

are no grammar rules that prohibit split
infinitives many English experts

strongly disapprove of them an example
of a split infinitive is the classic to

boldly go where no man has gone before
the word boldly and go should be the

other way round
it should read to go boldly where no man

has gone before in writing this looks
more dramatic but when spoken the split

infinitive sounds better so while the
use of a split infinitive is technically

incorrect you might only find the most
pedantic English teachers picking you up

on it to pick someone up on something is
to correct them by pointing out their mistake

it's not fair what will we do sadly it's
time to say goodbye to you and you and

you but never fear because I will be
back here very soon with another delve

into the fascinating and sometimes
confusing world of English don't forget

to hit that subscribe button and
activate the automatic notifications so

you will never miss another one of my
English lessons whether it be I recorded

one or a live one you'll be right here
with me

this is mr. duncan in England saying
thanks for joining me today take care
enjoy English and of course
ta ta for now.
